metadata.name: Language Data Commons Comprehensive Collection
metadata.description: Implements the language data commons RO-Crate Metadata Profile for the top-level, objects and files.
metadata.author: University of Queensland

inputGroups.name: About
inputGroups.help: The core metadata for this RO-Crate and its subject matter.

inputGroups.name: Related People, Orgs & Works
inputGroups.help: The context for the creation of this RO-Crate; who made it, funded it etc.

inputGroups.name: Structure
inputGroups.help: For groups of elements, such as DefinedTerms.

inputGroups.name: Provenance
inputGroups.help: Detailed description of how entities were created, by whom and with which tools.

inputGroups.name: Language
inputGroups.help: Metadata related to the languages used, modes of communication and other linguistic classifications.

inputGroups.name: Space & Time
inputGroups.help: Where and when the data was collected; the times and places it mentions or describes.

inputGroups.name: Software & Hardware
inputGroups.help: For computer programs and execution environments that could be used to create data, have created data, or are being packaged and described.

inputs.name: isAccessibleForFree
inputs.label: isAccessibleForFree
inputs.help: This is available under an Open Access license.

inputs.name: name
inputs.label: Name
inputs.help: The name of this dataset.

inputs.name: license
inputs.label: license
inputs.help: Link to a document that describes the rights and obligations for users of this collection record. NOTE: This does not necessarily cover the license terms that may apply to Objects in the collection which may have specific licensing. Licensing on other objects overrides the license attached to a collection record.

inputs.name: ldac:annotationOf
inputs.label: annotationOf
inputs.help: This resource contains some kind of description that adds information to the resource it references.

inputs.name: rightsHolder
inputs.label: rightsHolder
inputs.help: A person or organisation owning or managing rights over the resource.

inputs.name: isBasedOn
inputs.label: isBasedOn
inputs.help: Link to or description of an original resource at an institution that holds it.

inputs.name: creditText
inputs.label: creditText
inputs.help: A free text bibliographic citation for this material, e.g. 'Cite as: Musgrave (2023). Title of work. DOI'.

inputs.name: usageInfo
inputs.label: usageInfo
inputs.help: Additional information on licensing options for using the data, e.g. 'Contact the Data Steward to discuss license terms'.

inputs.name: author
inputs.label: author
inputs.help: The person or organisation responsible for creating this collection of data. Authors should be identified using URIs such as ORCiD or ROR.

inputs.name: accountablePerson
inputs.label: accountablePerson
inputs.help: The person or organisation who is the data steward for this resource.

inputs.name: publisher
inputs.label: publisher
inputs.help: The organisation responsible for releasing this dataset.

inputs.name: funder
inputs.label: funder
inputs.help: The organisation(s) responsible for funding the creation or collection of this dataset.

inputs.name: citation
inputs.label: citation
inputs.help: Associated publications.

inputs.name: description
inputs.label: description
inputs.help: An abstract of the collection. Include as much detail as possible about the motivation and use of the dataset, including things that we do not yet have properties for.

inputs.name: ldac:doi
inputs.label: DOI
inputs.help: A Digital Object Identifier, e.g. https://doi.org/10.1000/182.

inputs.name: temporalCoverage
inputs.label: temporalCoverage
inputs.help: The range of years of creation for items in this dataset using a slash, e.g. 1900/1945. If there are sub-collections with different coverages put this on the sub-collections not the top-level.

inputs.name: spatialCoverage
inputs.label: spatialCoverage
inputs.help: The place(s) that are the focus of the content. It is a sub-property of contentLocation intended primarily for more technical and detailed materials. For example, with a dataset, it indicates areas that the dataset describes: a dataset Cape York languages would have spatialCoverage which was the place: the outline of the Cape.

inputs.name: hasCollectionProtocol
inputs.label: hasCollectionProtocol
inputs.help: A link to a CollectionProtocol object with (at least) a summary of how resources were selected or elicited for this collection/sub-collection.

inputs.name: hasMember
inputs.label: hasMember
inputs.help: The sub-collections, if any, associated with this collection.

inputs.name: hasPart
inputs.label: hasPart
inputs.help: An item or CreativeWork that is part of this item, or CreativeWork (in some sense).

inputs.name: isPartOf
inputs.label: isPartOf
inputs.help: An item or CreativeWork that this item, or CreativeWork (in some sense), is part of.

inputs.name: memberOf
inputs.label: memberOf
inputs.help: Links from a Repository Object or Collection to a containing Repository Object or Collection.

inputs.name: datePublished
inputs.label: datePublished
inputs.help: The (earliest) date this work was created.

inputs.name: ldac:annotator
inputs.label: annotator
inputs.help: The participant produced an annotation of this or a related resource.

inputs.name: ldac:compiler
inputs.label: compiler
inputs.help: This refers to someone who creates a single resource with multiple parts, such as a book of short stories, or a person who produces a corpus of resources, which may be archived separately.

inputs.name: ldac:consultant
inputs.label: consultant
inputs.help: This term is commonly used by field linguists for the native speakers who work with them in describing and analysing a language. They contribute their expertise in their native language to the resource, although their speech, sign, or writing may not appear directly in the resource. In some parts of the world, the preferred term for this role is 'informant'.

inputs.name: ldac:dataInputter
inputs.label: dataInputter
inputs.help: The participant was responsible for entering, re-typing, and/or structuring the data contained in the resource.

inputs.name: ldac:depositor
inputs.label: depositor
inputs.help: The participant was responsible for depositing the resource in an archive.

inputs.name: ldac:developer
inputs.label: developer
inputs.help: A software programmer, designer, or analyst; a designer of a questionnaire or research task.

inputs.name: ldac:editor
inputs.label: editor
inputs.help: This role includes anyone whose role was editorial in nature, such as proofreaders, debuggers, testers, etc. It may overlap the Compiler role in some cases.

inputs.name: ldac:illustrator
inputs.label: illustrator
inputs.help: The participant contributed drawings or other illustrations to the resource.

inputs.name: ldac:interviewee
inputs.label: interviewee
inputs.help: The participant was a respondent in an interview.

inputs.name: ldac:interviewer
inputs.label: interviewer
inputs.help: The participant conducted an interview that forms part of the resource.

inputs.name: ldac:participant
inputs.label: participant
inputs.help: This role is intended for minor participants such as audience members or other peripherally involved participants in the event. These interlocutors need not have been physically present.

inputs.name: ldac:performer
inputs.label: performer
inputs.help: It is recommended that this term be used only for creative participants whose role is not better indicated by a more specific term, such as 'speaker', 'signer', or 'singer'.

inputs.name: ldac:photographer
inputs.label: photographer
inputs.help: The participant took the photograph, or shot the film, that appears in or constitutes the resource.

inputs.name: ldac:recorder
inputs.label: recorder
inputs.help: The participant operated the recording machinery used to create the resource.

inputs.name: ldac:researcher
inputs.label: researcher
inputs.help: The resource was created as part of the participant's research, or the research presents interim or final results from the participant's research.

inputs.name: ldac:researchParticipant
inputs.label: researchParticipant
inputs.help: The participant acted as a research subject or responded to a questionnaire, the results of which study form the basis of the resource.

inputs.name: ldac:responder
inputs.label: responder
inputs.help: This person's voice can be heard (or their words can be read) in the resource, typically saying the language-appropriate equivalent of "uh-huh", "amen", "you don't say", etc. This role is sometimes referred to as a "yes-sayer", "backchanneler", or "co-conversant".

inputs.name: ldac:signer
inputs.label: signer
inputs.help: Those whose gestures predominate in a recorded or filmed resource. (This resource may be a transcription of that recording).

inputs.name: ldac:singer
inputs.label: singer
inputs.help: The participant sang, either individually or as part of a group, in a resource that consists of a recording, a film, or a transcription of a recorded resource.

inputs.name: ldac:speaker
inputs.label: speaker
inputs.help: Those whose voices predominate in a recorded or filmed resource. (This resource may be a transcription of that recording).

inputs.name: ldac:sponsor
inputs.label: sponsor
inputs.help: The participant contributed financial support to the creation of the resource.

inputs.name: ldac:transcriber
inputs.label: transcriber
inputs.help: The participant produced a transcription of this or a related resource.

inputs.name: ldac:translator
inputs.label: translator
inputs.help: The participant produced a translation of this or a related resource.

inputs.name: contentLocation
inputs.label: contentLocation
inputs.help: The location depicted or described in the content. For example, the location in a photograph or painting.

inputs.name: conformsTo
inputs.label: conformsTo
inputs.help: A link to the Text Commons RO-Crate profile for collections.

inputs.name: inLanguage
inputs.label: inLanguage
inputs.help: The language in which the resource is written.

inputs.name: ldac:subjectLanguage
inputs.label: subjectLanguage
inputs.help: The languages that the materials in the collection are about (not the language that it is in).

inputs.name: dateCreated
inputs.label: dateCreated
inputs.help: The (earliest) date the data in this dataset were created.

inputs.name: ldac:dateFreeText
inputs.label: dateFreeText
inputs.help: Date information which cannot be put in one of the standard date formats, e.g. 'mid-1970s', or it is not clear, for example, if it is a creation or publication date.

inputs.name: holdingArchive
inputs.label: HoldingArchive
inputs.help: Organisation where the original of this work or collection is housed.

inputs.name: isBasedOn
inputs.label: isBasedOn
inputs.help: Link to a version of this data in an online archival repository.

inputs.name: hasPart
inputs.label: hasPart
inputs.help: An item or CreativeWork that is part of this item, or CreativeWork (in some sense).

inputs.name: conformsTo
inputs.label: conformsTo
inputs.help: A link to the Text Commons RO-Crate profile for collections.

inputs.name: publisher
inputs.label: publisher
inputs.help: The publisher of the creative work.

inputs.name: creator
inputs.label: creator
inputs.help: The creator/author of this CreativeWork. This is the same as the Author property for CreativeWork.

inputs.name: ldac:compiler
inputs.label: compiler
inputs.help: The contributor responsible for collecting the sub-parts of the resource together.

inputs.name: description
inputs.label: description
inputs.help: A description of the item.

inputs.name: datePublished
inputs.label: datePublished
inputs.help: The (earliest) date this work was created.

inputs.name: temporalCoverage
inputs.label: temporalCoverage
inputs.help:
The temporalCoverage of a CreativeWork indicates the period that the content applies to, i.e. that it describes, either as a DateTime or as a textual string indicating a time period in [ISO 8601 time interval format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Time_intervals). In
      the case of a Dataset it will typically indicate the relevant time period in a precise notation (e.g. for a 2011 census dataset, the year 2011 would be written "2011/2012"). Other forms of content, e.g. ScholarlyArticle, Book, TVSeries or TVEpisode, may indicate their temporalCoverage in broader terms - textually or via well-known URL.
      Written works such as books may sometimes have precise temporal coverage too, e.g. a work set in 1939 - 1945 can be indicated in ISO 8601 interval format format via "1939/1945".

Open-ended date ranges can be written with ".." in place of the end date. For example, "2015-11/.." indicates a range beginning in November 2015 and with no specified final date. This is tentative and might be updated in future when ISO 8601 is officially updated.

inputs.name: identifier
inputs.label: identifier
inputs.help: The identifier property represents any kind of identifier for any kind of [[Thing]], such as ISBNs, GTIN codes, UUIDs etc. Schema.org provides dedicated properties for representing many of these, either as textual strings or as URL (URI) links. See [background notes](/docs/datamodel.html#identifierBg) for more details.

values.description: The resource contains non-linguistic gestural communication (i.e. not sign language).
values.name: Gesture

values.description: The resource contains data for which the medium of interaction was signing.

values.description: The resource contains data for which the medium of interaction was song.

inputs.name: name
inputs.label: name
inputs.help: The name of the item.

inputs.name: license
inputs.label: license
inputs.help: A license document that applies to this content, typically indicated by URL.

inputs.name: ldac:linguisticGenre
inputs.label: linguisticGenre
inputs.help: A linguistic classification of the genre of this resource.

values.description: An interactive discourse with two or more participants. Examples of dialogues include conversations, interviews, correspondence, consultations, greetings and leave-takings.
values.name: Dialogue

values.description: A planned, creative rendition of discourse with two or more participants intended for presentation to an audience.
values.name: Drama

values.description: The resource is a ritually or conventionally structured discourse.
values.name: Formulaic

values.description: Discourse whose primary purpose is to inform the audience about the natural or social world.
values.name: Informational

values.description: The resource is a conversation where one or more speakers are directing the conversation.
values.name: Interview

values.description: The resource includes a systematic listing of lexical items.
values.name: Lexicon

values.description: Language whose primary function is to be part of play, or a style of speech that involves a creative manipulation of the structures of the language. Examples of ludic discourse are play languages, jokes, secret languages, and speech disguises.
values.name: Ludic

values.description: A discourse, monologic or co-constructed, which represents temporally organised events. Types of narratives include historical, traditional, and personal narratives, myths, folktales, fables, and humorous stories.
values.name: Narrative

values.description: The art of public speaking, or of speaking eloquently according to rules or conventions. Examples of oratory include sermons, lectures, political speeches, and invocations.
values.name: Oratory

values.description: An explanation or description of a method, process, or situation having ordered steps.
values.name: Procedural

values.description: A factual account of some event or circumstance.
values.name: Report

values.description: The resource contains a list or data structure consisting of words or concepts arranged according to sense.
values.name: Thesaurus

The temporalCoverage of a CreativeWork indicates the period that the content applies to, i.e. that it describes, either as a DateTime or as a textual string indicating a time period in [ISO 8601 time interval format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Time_intervals). In
      the case of a Dataset it will typically indicate the relevant time period in a precise notation (e.g. for a 2011 census dataset, the year 2011 would be written "2011/2012"). Other forms of content, e.g. ScholarlyArticle, Book, TVSeries or TVEpisode, may indicate their temporalCoverage in broader terms - textually or via well-known URL.
      Written works such as books may sometimes have precise temporal coverage too, e.g. a work set in 1939 - 1945 can be indicated in ISO 8601 interval format format via "1939/1945".

Open-ended date ranges can be written with ".." in place of the end date. For example, "2015-11/.." indicates a range beginning in November 2015 and with no specified final date. This is tentative and might be updated in future when ISO 8601 is officially updated.

inputs.name: ldac:materialType

inputs.help: Indicates whether the material in a file is the original (primary) source or is derived from it or describes it via annotation.

values.description: The object of study, such as a literary work, film, or recording of natural discourse.
values.name: PrimaryMaterial

values.description: The resource includes material that adds information to some other linguistic record.
values.name: Annotation

values.description: This is derived from another source, such as a Primary Material, via some process, e.g. a downsampled video or a sample or an abstract of a resource that is not an annotation (an analysis or description).
values.name: DerivedMaterial

values.description: An interactive discourse with two or more participants. Examples of dialogues include conversations, interviews, correspondence, consultations, greetings and leave-takings.

values.description: The resource is a ritually or conventionally structured discourse.
values.name: Formulaic

values.description: Discourse whose primary purpose is to inform the audience about the natural or social world.
values.name: Informational

values.description: The resource is a conversation where one or more speakers are directing the conversation.
values.name: Interview

values.description: The resource includes a systematic listing of lexical items.
values.name: Lexicon

values.description: Language whose primary function is to be part of play, or a style of speech that involves a creative manipulation of the structures of the language. Examples of ludic discourse are play languages, jokes, secret languages, and speech disguises.
values.name: Ludic

values.description: A discourse, monologic or co-constructed, which represents temporally organised events. Types of narratives include historical, traditional, and personal narratives, myths, folktales, fables, and humorous stories.
values.name: Narrative

values.description: The art of public speaking, or of speaking eloquently according to rules or conventions. Examples of oratory include sermons, lectures, political speeches, and invocations.
values.name: Oratory

values.description: An explanation or description of a method, process, or situation having ordered steps.
values.name: Procedural

values.description: A factual account of some event or circumstance.
values.name: Report

values.description: The resource contains a list or data structure consisting of words or concepts arranged according to sense.
values.name: Thesaurus

inputs.name: ldac:annotationType
inputs.label: annotationType
inputs.help: Specifies the type of an Annotation resource.

inputs.name: size
inputs.label: size
inputs.help: The size in bytes.
